text: [Music]
there is a an open question to this day
among historians as to how much credit
Reagan deserves for having brought the
Cold War to an end as opposed to purely
internal conditions in effect the
internal contradictions of the Soviet
Union which were leading to a speedy
collapse where maybe Reagan gave it a
push but not much more than that if you
ask the people who came after him the
bush W foreign policy team they would
say it had much less to do with American
rhetorical exhortation and much more to
do with the Soviet Union just couldn't
survive anymore I I think what I did say
though and what I do say in the
book is that Reagan was the first person
who tried to institutionalize this idea
of democracy promotion he created
institutions that are called the
national Democratic Institute and the
international Republican Institute these
are connected to each party which work
under an organization called the
National Endowment for democracy so this
is an attempt to actually
institutionalize in in private by bodies
though funded by the government this act
of democracy promotion So Reagan gets
credit for that the other thing he gets
credit for is but it took him a long
time to get there the recognition that
we could not keep supporting these
right-wing dictators who were
pro-american in their Cold War policy
but were despised by their population
and so that happened in South Korea it
happened in the Philippines it happened
in Chile and in each case it's important
to say Reagan defended these guys to the
last and then finally was persuaded by
people in his own Administration that
this was bad for us and bad for them and
then finally we cut them loose and that
had a really positive outcome
[Music]
